newsitem.title: FRANCE: Suspended terms urged for French zinc plant bosses.
newsitem.headline: Suspended terms urged for French zinc plant bosses.

text.p: A prosecutor on Friday urged suspended jail terms and modest fines for two former managers of a French zinc plant where explosions killed 11 workers in 1993 and 1994.

Lawyers for the families said the recommended sentences were too lenient. "What has been given here is a genuine licence to kill," said Charles Lederman, an attorney representing victims' families and a labour union participating in the trial.
Prosecutor Patrick Desjardins faulted safety procedures at the plant, owned by French zinc and lead producer Metaleurop, and said it seemed the safety situation at the plant was "a big mess".
"It is too easy to blame fate," he said.
Jean Neret, attorney for the two managers, urged that they be acquitted of manslaughter.

Desjardins recommended a two-year suspended sentence plus a fine of 30,000 francs ($5,250) for Pierre Vix, who ran the Metaleurop plant in Noyelles-Godault, northeastern France, during the first explosion in July 1993, in which 10 workers died.

For Jean-Jacques Dailloux, who was running the plant at the time of the second blast in January 1994 in which an 11th employee died, he urged an 18-month suspended sentence and an identical 30,000-franc ($5,250) fine.

He noted the managers were being tried under a provision of the penal code, since rewritten, allowing a maximum sentence of two years in prison. The new version of the code allows prison terms of up to five years.
The court's judgment will be released on September 25.
A judicial probe of the deaths, conducted before the trial which began on Tuesday, had uncovered "safety shortfalls" at the plant.

Investigating magistrate Benoit Persyn said in a court submission based on legal and technical analyses that "certain steps could have been taken, if not to avoid the explosions, at least to avoid the deaths of a hefty number of victims".
Safety at the plant "had made no advances in 15 years", the magistrate said. Before both explosions, cracking, vibration and unusual noises had been noticed by plant operators.
Four of the 11 who died were permanent Metaleurop staff, while the others had been hired through temporary work agencies.
